properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Culgoa township.

  • Flood levels are rising along the Tyrrell Creek. Floodwater may impact the township of Culgoa and properties to the North as it continues to flow along the Tyrrell Creek.
  • This flood may reach a similar level to the flood of September 2010.
Prepare for flooding now. Take actions to protect your life and property against potential hazards caused by flooding.
What you should do:
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and warnings.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around and find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area:
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is may to occur in some locations.
  • Sea Lake-Swan Hill Road may be impacted due to floodwater. For more information on road closures go to traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 09:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Major Flood Warning is being issued for Wharparilla area.. 

  • Flooding is currently starting to impact residents in the area of Glyn Road, Wharparilla.
Move to higher ground. Act now - immediately take actions to protect your life and property.
What you should do: 
Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater. 
Decide if you will evacuate if it becomes necessary. 

If you choose to leave: 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave. 
If you are travelling: 
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around and find a safe alternative route. 
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.     
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated. 
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow. 
Stay informed - listen to emergency broadcasters and monitor warnings.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in many locations. 
  • A small number of properties are likely to be impacted in or around Glyn Road Wharparilla.
  • Roads around the Glyn Road Wharparilla area may be staring to be impacted.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 03:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

This Flood Watch is being issued for Dimboola.

The Wimmera River atQuantong Bridge is above the minor flood level and falling, slowly. Minor flooding is likely to continue during Thursday.

The Wimmera River Upstream (U/S) Dimboola is currently rising, below the minor flood level. The Wimmera River Upstream (U/S) Dimboola is expected to remain below the minor flood level during Thursday into Friday.

Floodwater may impact the low lying areas to the south of Dimboola, and areas adjacent to Anderson Street and Picnic Bend Road, south of Dimboola.  

Flooding may impact the Dimboola Golf Course, parts of the Dimboola Caravan Park, and the Dimboola Recreation Reserve Netball Courts.  

Flooding may impact the river end of Wimmera Street, Horseshoe Bend Road and Riverside Road. 
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do:

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 02:00 pm or as the situation changes.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Kialla West


Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater. 
What you should do:

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 
  • Find alternative travel routes if roads or underpasses are flooded. 
  • Be aware of driving hazards, such as mud, debris, damaged roads and fallen trees.  
  • If returning to the area, keep travel to a minimum, drive slowly and carefully as properties are still being assessed by emergency services and floodwater still covers many roads.
  • If cleaning after damage has occurred, protect your health and safety. 
  • Wear strong boots, gloves and protective clothing and wash your hands and clothes regularly. 

If you are returning to your home or business and it has been flooded:  
  • Check for building damage before you enter. 
  • Only turn your power on at the main electrical switchboard if water has not entered the property.  
  • If water has entered your property, do not put the power back on until the property wiring has been tested by a licensed electrician.  
  • If any appliances have been inundated, do not plug them in or switch them on until they have been tested by a licensed electrician.  
  • Any damaged gas or electricity supplies need to be professionally tested and declared safe by a qualified electrician or plumber.  
  • Do not use a portable generator indoors, they can produce carbon monoxide gas which could build up in a confined space and make you sick or be fatal.   
  •  For more information visit: https://esv.vic.gov.au/safety-education/emergencies/electrical-emergency/ 
  • Clean and dry out the building as soon as possible. 
  • Flooding can cause sewage to overflow inside your home. Contact with sewage can make people sick, so contaminated areas must be cleaned and disinfected.  
  • Food safety should also be considered and ALL food that has been flood damaged should be thrown away, including canned and packaged foods.  

Flood Recovery Hotline is a single state-wide number, 1800 560 760, that Victorians impacted by the October 2022 floods can call for help or assistance with: Register for clean-up on private property;  Navigating financial and other support;  Access to temporary accommodation;  Mental health and wellbeing support.  The recovery hotline is open from 7:30am-7:30pm everyday.   Call 1800 560 760 (press 9 to speak to an interpreter).   

Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. For emergency assistance from the SES call 132 500.

Impacts in your area:
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.
  • Damage to roads and buildings caused by flooding may still exist in your area. 
Wildlife 
  • For assistance with injured wildlife (away from floodwaters), please contact your local wildlife carer or rescue group or call Wildlife Victoria on (03) 8400 7300.    
  • Anyone seeing animals that appear injured as a result of flooding or caught in floodwater should call the DELWP Customer Service Centre on 136 186. 
Health impacts 
  • Private water supplies may also be contaminated from floodwater, debris and chemicals. If your water supply tastes, looks or smells unusual, do not use it for drinking, preparing food, and do not give it to animals.  
  • Medicines, stored at home and affected by flood water may now be unsafe and extreme caution should be taken in trying to salvage any medicines.  
  • Mosquitoes can also breed rapidly in stagnant waters. Drain any water from containers such as plant pots, tyres, buckets, and roof gutters to control mosquitos around your home. 
  • Flooding can also cause excessive mould growth which must be cleaned up before moving back to your home as it can make you sick. 
  •  It is important to look after your mental health and that of friends, family and neighbours. If at any time you are worried about your mental health or the mental health of a loved one, call Lifeline 13 11 14 or the Suicide Call Back Service on 1300 659 467.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 22/10/2022 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Register Find Unite - Red Cross  
Red Cross has opened Register.Find.Reunite. and is urging people affected by the Victorian Floods to get in touch with their families and friends. Register.Find.Reunite. helps find and reunite family, friends and loved ones during a disaster. People can register on the Red Cross website at register.redcross.org.au, or by phone at 1800 727 077.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Shepparton.

MAJOR FLOODING CONTINUING AT McCOYS BRIDGE

  • Major flooding is occurring along the Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton.
  • The Goulburn River at McCoys Bridge is currently at 10.55 metres and steady, with major flooding. 
  • The Goulburn River at McCoys Bridge is likely to remain above the major flood level (10.20 m) for the remainder of Thursday into Friday.
The Causeway between Shepparton and Mooroopna is now open. Please obey all traffic restrictions.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater. 
What you should do:

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Impacts in your area:
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.
  • Main roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
  • Snakes, spiders and rats may try to find shelter in your home, even if raised.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 04:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • Returning home
  •  Only turn your power on at the main electrical switchboard if water has not entered the property. If water has entered your property, do not put the power back on until the property wiring has been tested by a licensed electrician. If any appliances have been inundated, do not plug them in or switch them on until they have been tested by a licensed electrician. For more information visit: https://esv.vic.gov.au/safety-education/emergencies/electrical-emergency/  
  •  Recovery :
  • Flood Recovery Hotline is a single state-wide number, 1800 560 760, that Victorians impacted by the October 2022 floods can call for help or assistance with: navigating available supports mental health and wellbeing support The recovery hotline is open from 7:30am-7:30pm everyday.   Call 1800 560 760 If your home is flooding and you need emergency assistance Call 000 If your home is about to flood Call VICSES on 132 500    
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Wimmera River Glenorchy to Horsham: Moderate flooding is occurring along the Wimmera River Glenorchy to Horsham. 

Wimmera River downstream of Horsham: Minor flooding is occurring along the Wimmera River downstream of Horsham. The Wimmera River at Quantong Bridge is above the minor flood level and falling, slowly. Minor flooding is likely to continue during Thursday.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is for Bunbartha.
  • An evacuation warning remains current. It is still not safe to return.
  • Dangerous flood water and road closures remain, continue to avoid flood-affected areas.
It is not safe for people to return to Bunbartha. If you have not evacuated, you should now shelter in the highest location possible.
What you should do:

If you have not already evacuated:
  • Stay where you are and shelter in the highest location possible.
  • Be aware that you may be isolated by floodwater for a significant amount of time.
  • Check you have enough food, drinking water and medications - if you do not, phone 132 500 for assistance.
If you have already evacuated:
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued.
  • Register at a relief centre so that your friends, family and authorities can be informed that you are safe.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.

This evacuation warning is likely to remain in place until further notice.
Impacts in your area:
  • You may lose services including power, water, sewerage and telephone due to flooding.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 06:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is for Loddon Weir to Kerang. 

  • An Evacuation Warning remains current, but it is now too late to leave. 
  • The flood is expected to impact the surrounding areas of Kerang and peak on Friday, 21 October 2022. This means there is no longer enough time to safely leave your property. 
  • This Emergency Warning replaces the Evacuate Immediately Emergency Warning issued at 2.30pm.
  • The Murray Valley Highway is now closed. 
It is now too late to leave for people in Kerang Township. If you have not evacuated, you should shelter in place.
What you should do: 

If you have not already evacuated: 
  • Stay where you are and shelter in place. 
  • Be aware that you may be isolated by floodwater for a significant amount of time. 
  • Check you have enough food, drinking water and medications - if you do not, phone Triple Zero (000) for assistance. 

If you have already evacuated: 
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued. 
  • Register at a relief centre so that your friends, family and authorities can be informed that you are safe. 
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings. 

Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 

This evacuation warning is likely to remain in place for several days.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Flood levels remain above that of a single-story home. 
  • Based on historic data, this flood is likely to have a similar impact as the January 2011 Floods, which resulted in flooding in properties surrounding Kerang which isolated the Kerang Township.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 09:30 am or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 

Accessibility:

properties.location: Upper Murray and Mitta Mitta Rivers
properties.webBody:
This Flood Watch is being issued for the Upper Murray and Mitta Mitta Rivers.

Renewed river level rises are expected and minor to moderate flooding may develop in the flood watch area from Saturday.

A low pressure system is forecast to bring rainfall and thunderstorms across Victoria from Friday, with the potential for isolated heavy falls. It will be followed by another rain-bearing system over the weekend for central and eastern parts of the state. Further widespread showers and rain are possible for early next week.

Catchments in the Flood Watch area are saturated, many of which are experiencing ongoing flooding due to recent rainfall.

Renewed river level rises are expected and minor to moderate flooding may develop in the watch area from Saturday. Catchments with existing warnings where river levels are elevated may see renewed flooding potentially to major flood levels from early next week at some locations. Renewed river rises are not expected to increase the currently forecast major flood peaks along the Murray River.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do:
  • Decide what you and your family will do if flooding impacts you. For information on how to prepare go to www.ses.vic.gov.au/get-ready/floodsafe.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Review your emergency plan and check your emergency kit is fully stocked, if you have one.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 
  • High river levels and surrounding areas may be flooded.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 02:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Broken River downstream of Casey Weir
properties.webBody:
This is a Final Minor Flood Warning for Broken River downstream of Casey Weir. 

  • FLOODING EASED AT ORRVALE
  • River levels along the Broken River are continuing to ease at Casey Weir, Benalla and Orrvale, where river levels are below the minor flood level.
  • Further rainfall is forecast from Thursday, which may lead to renewed river level rises. The situation is being closely monitored, and warnings will be issued as necessary.
    • Broken River downstream of Casey Weir. 
  • River levels are continuing to ease along the Broken River downstream of Casey Weir.
  • The Broken River at Orrvale peaked at 8.33 metres around 09:00 am Monday and is currently at 6.12 metres and falling, below the minor flood level. The Broken River at Orrvale is expected to remain below the minor flood level (6.80 m) for the next few days. Renewed river level rises are expected with the forecast rainfall.
The threat of flooding is reduced. Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and beware of hazards remaining in the warning area.
What you should do:

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.

If your home or business has been flooded:
  • Check for building damage before you enter.
  • Have all electrical and gas equipment professionally tested before use.
  • Returning home 
  •  Only turn your power on at the main electrical switchboard if water has not entered the property. If water has entered your property, do not put the power back on until the property wiring has been tested by a licensed electrician. If any appliances have been inundated, do not plug them in or switch them on until they have been tested by a licensed electrician. For more information visit: https://esv.vic.gov.au/safety-education/emergencies/electrical-emergency/   
  • Recovery : 
  •  Flood Recovery Hotline is a single state-wide number, 1800 560 760, that Victorians impacted by the October 2022 floods can call for help or assistance with: navigating available supports mental health and wellbeing support The recovery hotline is open from 7:30am-7:30pm everyday.   Call 1800 560 760 If your home is flooding and you need emergency assistance Call 000 If your home is about to flood Call VICSES on 132 500    
  • Clean and dry out the building as soon as possible.

Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. For emergency assistance from the SES call 132 500.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Damage to roads and buildings caused by flooding may still exist in your area. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

This will be the last warning for this flood. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Mosquito Alert: 
With the recent floods in many areas across Victoria, the risk of mosquito breeding is high. You can reduce your risk of being bitten and getting sick by:
  • Cover up - wear long, loose-fitting clothing 
  • Use repellents that contain picaridin or DEET 
  • Use mosquito nets or insect screens.
  • Limit activity outdoors and move indoors if possible. 
Learn more about how to protect yourself and your family at www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/campaigns/beat-the-bite

properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Broken Creek Catchment.

MINOR FLOODING CONTINUING ALONG THE BROKEN CREEK AT WALSHS BRIDGE AND NATHALIA
Heavy rainfall during Wednesday and Thursday last week has caused river level rises along the Boosey Creek, Muckatah Creek and Broken Creek. Minor flooding will continue along the Broken Creek at Walshs Bridge and at Nathalia for the next few days.
River levels in and around Numurkah are expected to see rises similar to that of the December 2010 event in coming days.
Further rainfall is forecast from Thursday, which may lead to renewed river level rises. The situation is being closely monitored, and warnings will be updated as necessary.
Broken Creek:
Minor flooding is occurring along the Broken Creek.
The Broken Creek at Walshs Bridge is currently at 2.42 metres and rising slowly, with minor flooding.
The Broken Creek at Nathalia is currently at 1.59 metres and rising slowly, with minor flooding. The Broken Creek at Nathalia is likely to remain above the minor flood level (1.50 m) for the next few days.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Access further information from the Numurkah and/or Nathalia Local Flood Guide at ses.vic.gov.au
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.  
  • No heavy vehicles on Goulburn Valley Highway to Shepparton, use alternate route to Wangaratta via Bundalong on the Murray Valley Highway.
  •  Due to recent rainfalls roads have significantly deteriorated, drive with extreme caution.
  •  Animals are taking refuge on roadways, drive with caution and remain vigilant of wildlife.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 01:40 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • For road closure information go to www.traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au or phone 13 11 70.
  • Floods and animals.  
  •  If there is potential for flooding in your area, move your animals, fodder and machinery to higher ground early if it is safe to do so.   Relocate and separate bulls and stallions from the mob in flood-prone areas when a flood alert is issued. They are not suitable for holding in confined spaces on a flood mound with other animals.  Maintain several days of feed reserves above the flood level as wet conditions may make farm roads impassable.   Check animals that have been standing in mud or water for extended periods for health problems. For more information go to: https://agriculture.vic.gov.au/farm-management/emergency-management/floods/how-to-prepare-for-flood

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for parts of Echuca and Echuca Village. 
If you live, work or are holidaying in this area, you should Evacuate Immediately. 

Major flooding is occurring along the Murray River at Echuca, Moama, Torrumbarry, Barham.

MURRAY RIVER
  • The Murray River at Echuca may reach around 94.80 metres during Sunday, with major flooding. This level is similar to the October 1993 flood event (94.77 m AHD). The river level may possibly reach around 95.00 metres during Tuesday.

CAMPASPE RIVER
  •  Moderate flooding is continuing along the Campaspe River at Echuca. 
  • Further rainfall is forecast from Friday. A flood watch is current, advising of the potential for renewed flooding
  • Flooding may impact residents whose properties surround the Campaspe River. 
  • Residents in Echuca Village can expect to be impacted over the coming days.
If you are located in the warning areas, it is recommended you Evacuate Immediately. If you do not relocate now you may become isolated for a number of days. If you choose to stay, emergency services may not be able to help you. The EVACUATION ROUTE is currently open but may not stay that way.

The Bendigo Emergency Relief Centre (Bendigo Showgrounds) is being utilised as primary relief centre for the area. People should expect there may be a requirement to be moved to Bendigo from Echuca Emergency Relief Centre (Echuca South Basketball Stadium).

Flood water is impacting sewerage systems in Echuca. Please consider minimising water use, including the use of washing machines and dishwashers, and limit baths and showers. This will reduce the volume of water being sent to sewer while flood levels are high. 
What you should do: 

Travel to a safe location. Options include: 
  • Travel to family and friends outside of the impacted area.
  • Travel direct to Bendigo Relief Centre, Bendigo Showgrounds, Holmes Road Bendigo.
  • If assistance is required to travel, please attend Echuca South Basketball Stadium, 244 High Street, Echuca South.
  • For evacuation route follow this link: Evacuation Route
If you are travelling by car: 
  • Do not drive through floodwater. 
  • Find alternative travel routes if roads or underpasses are flooded. 
  • Be aware of driving hazards, such as mud, debris, damaged roads and fallen trees. 
  • If driving conditions are dangerous, safely pull over away from trees, drains, low lying areas and floodwater. 
If you stay:  
  • Stay inside and be aware of changing conditions. 
  • If floodwater comes inside, move to a higher point such as a kitchen bench or second story. 
  • Follow your emergency plan, if you have one. 
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation, if safe to do so. 
  • If you choose to stay, emergency services may not be able to help you
You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings. Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. 

For emergency assistance from the SES, call 132 500.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Evacuating too late or choosing to remain in your home when recommended to evacuate, is dangerous and may put your life at risk. 
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur. 
  • Areas near the affected location may lose services including power, water, sewerage and phone coverage due to flooding.
  • Some residents may notice their toilets arent flushing or sinks arent draining as normal. Please consider minimising water use, including the use of washing machines and dishwashers, and limit baths and showers. This will to reduce the volume of water being sent to sewer while flood levels are high.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 12:00 pm or as the situation changes. 

Mosquito Alert:  
With the recent floods in many areas across Victoria, the risk of mosquito breeding is high. You can reduce your risk of being bitten and getting sick by: 
  • Cover up - wear long, loose-fitting clothing 
  • Use repellents that contain picaridin or DEET
  • Use mosquito nets or insect screens
  • Limit activity outdoors and move indoors if possible. 
Learn more about how to protect yourself and your family at www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/campaigns/beat-the-bite

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Cover up - wear long, loose-fitting clothing  
  • Use repellents that contain picaridin or DEET 
  • Use mosquito nets or insect screens.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Southern end of Murchison Township.
  • MODERATE FLOODING OCCURRING DOWNSTREAM OF LAKE EILDON, SEYMOUR AND SHEPPARTON AND MINOR FLOODING IS OCCURRING AT MURCHISON.
  • Goulburn River Seymour to Shepparton:
  • Moderate flooding is easing along the Goulburn River between Seymour and Shepparton.
  • The Goulburn River at Murchison is currently at 10.09 metres and falling, with minor flooding. 
  • The Goulburn River at Murchison is likely to remain above the minor flood level (9.00 m) for the remainder of Thursday and into Friday.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater. 
What you should do:

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
  • Power/electricity restoration:
  • Only turn your power on at the main electrical switchboard if water has not entered the property. If water has entered your property, do not put the power back on until the property wiring has been tested by a licensed electrician. If any appliances have been inundated, do not plug them in or switch them on until they have been tested by a licensed electrician. 
Impacts in your area:
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 11:20 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • Recovery : 
  •  Flood Recovery Hotline is a single state-wide number, 1800 560 760, that Victorians impacted by the October 2022 floods can call for help or assistance with: navigating available supports mental health and wellbeing support The recovery hotline is open from 7:30am-7:30pm everyday.   Call 1800 560 760 If your home is flooding and you need emergency assistance Call 000 If your home is about to flood Call VICSES on 132 500
Accessibility:

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Mooroopna

This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch and Act - Not Safe to Return issued at 2.32am 20/10/2022. 

Dangerous flood water and road closures remain, continue to avoid flood-affected aeas.  A relief centre is open at Deakin Reserve (cnr Dixon St & Harold St) in Shepparton.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater. 
What you should do:
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off all switches at the main electrical switchboard, including the Main Switch. 
  • Unplug all your appliances and if you can, lift them up so they will remain clear of any floodwater that may inundate your property. 
  • Turn your solar system off at the inverter and then turn off at the switchboard (all switches on the switchboard should be in the OFF position). The solar system will have information on shut down procedures. 
  • Turn solar batteries off. Follow the shutdown procedure which will be close to battery system. Do not attempt to disassemble the battery or open any of the panels. 
  • You should turn off your gas supply by locating your gas meter and turning the gas supply service valve to the OFF position by rotating the handle to so that it is horizontal. 
  • Make sure all LPG cylinders are closed (clockwise to close the cylinder valve) at the valve on top of the cylinder. Do not disconnect any appliance unless the LPG cylinder is being relocated away from danger.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around and find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Stay informed - listen to emergency broadcasters (https://www.emv.vic.gov.au/responsibilities/victorias-warning-system/emergency-broadcasters/list) and monitor warnings.
Impacts in your area:
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • You may lose services including power, water, sewerage and telephone due to flooding.
  • Main roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding.

This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
Register Find Unite - Red Cross 
Red Cross has opened Register.Find.Reunite. and is urging people affected by the Victorian Floods to get in touch with their families and friends. Register.Find.Reunite. helps find and reunite family, friends and loved ones during a disaster. People can register on the Red Cross website at register.redcross.org.au, or by phone at 1800 727 077.

properties.webBody:
This Flood Watch is being issued for Goulburn River upstream of Lake Eildon to Seymour.

  • Renewed river level rises are expected and minor to moderate flooding may develop in the flood watch area from Saturday 
  • A low pressure system is forecast to bring rainfall and thunderstorms across Victoria from Friday, with the potential for isolated heavy falls. 
  • It will be followed by another rain-bearing system over the weekend for central and eastern parts of the state. Further widespread showers and rain are possible for early next week. 
  •  Catchments in the Flood Watch area are saturated, many of which are experiencing ongoing flooding due to recent rainfall. 
  • Renewed river level rises are expected and minor to moderate flooding may develop in the watch area from Saturday. 
  • Catchments with existing warnings where river levels are elevated may see renewed flooding potentially to major flood levels from early next week at some locations. 
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do:
  • Decide what you and your family will do if flooding impacts you. For information on how to prepare go to www.ses.vic.gov.au/get-ready/floodsafe.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Areas around rivers and streams may be flooded.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 02:00 pm or as the situation changes.

This Flood Watch is being issued for the Kiewa River to Mongans Bridge.

Renewed river level rises are expected and minor to moderate flooding may develop in the flood watch area from Saturday.

A low pressure system is forecast to bring rainfall and thunderstorms across Victoria from Friday, with the potential for isolated heavy falls. It will be followed by another rain-bearing system over the weekend for central and eastern parts of the state. Further widespread showers and rain are possible for early next week.

Catchments in the Flood Watch area are saturated, many of which are experiencing ongoing flooding due to recent rainfall.

Renewed river level rises are expected and minor to moderate flooding may develop in the watch area from Saturday. Catchments with existing warnings where river levels are elevated may see renewed flooding potentially to major flood levels from early next week at some locations. Renewed river rises are not expected to increase the currently forecast major flood peaks along the Murray River.

A Minor Flood Warning from previous rainfall is current for the Kiewa River downstream of Mongans Bridge.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do:

properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Seven Creeks downstream of Euroa.

MODERATE FLOODING EASING AT KIALLA WEST

Moderate flooding is continuing to ease along the Seven Creeks at Kialla West.

Further rainfall is forecast from Friday.  A flood watch is current advising of the potential for renewed flooding.  The situation is being monitored, and warnings will be updated as necessary.

Seven Creeks downstream of Euroa
Moderate flooding is easing along the Seven Creeks downstream of Euroa.

The Seven Creeks at Kialla West is currently at 5.15 metres and falling, with moderate flooding.  The Seven Creeks at Kialla West is likely to fall below the moderate flood level (5.00m) overnight Thursday into Friday.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater. 
What you should do:

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 
  • Find alternative travel routes if roads or underpasses are flooded. 
  • Be aware of driving hazards, such as mud, debris, damaged roads and fallen trees.  
  • Drive slowly, obey all roadblocks and never drive through floodwaters.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around and find a safe alternative route.
  • For more information on road closures go to traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Stay informed - listen to emergency broadcasters (https://www.emv.vic.gov.au/responsibilities/victorias-warning-system/emergency-broadcasters/list) and monitor warnings.
Impacts in your area:
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Main roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding.

This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 11:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is for Murchison East.
  • With the current flood levels in the township, it is still not safe to return.
  • With dangerous flood water and the ongoing closure of the Murchison Bridge, residents are reminded to continue to avoid flood-affected areas.
It is not safe for people to return to Murchison East. If you have not evacuated, you should now shelter in the highest location possible.
What you should do:

If you have not already evacuated:
  • Stay where you are and shelter in the highest location possible.
  • Be aware that you may be isolated by floodwater for a significant amount of time.
  • Check you have enough food, drinking water and medications - if you do not, phone Triple Zero (000) for assistance.
If you have already evacuated:
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued.
  • Register at a relief centre so that your friends, family and authorities can be informed that you are safe.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.

This evacuation warning is likely to remain in place until 11AM, 21st October.
Impacts in your area:
  • Flood levels remain above that of a single-storey home.
  • Stagnant water can be harmful to your health.  Don't drink, swim or wash in stagnant water.
  • The Murchison Bridge on High Road linking Murchison and Murchison East is now closed to traffic and physically barricaded until the structural integrity of the bridge is assessed. For more information on road closures go to traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 11:20 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:

  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Nathalia-Picola-Barmah and nearby areas.
  • Flooding is expected within the Nathalia, Picola and Barmah areas.
Prepare for flooding now. Take actions to protect your life and property against potential hazards caused by increases in flooding.
What you should do:
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Turn off all switches at the main electrical switchboard, including the Main Switch. 
  • Unplug all your appliances and if you can, lift them up so they will remain clear of any floodwater that may inundate your property. 
  • Turn your solar system off at the inverter and then turn off at the switchboard (all switches on the switchboard should be in the OFF position).  
  • Turn solar batteries off. Follow the shutdown procedure which will be close to battery system. Do not attempt to disassemble the battery or open any of the panels. 
  • You should turn off your gas supply by locating your gas meter and turning the gas supply service valve to the OFF position by rotating the handle to so that it is horizontal. 
  • Before evacuating, make sure all LPG cylinders are closed (clockwise to close the cylinder valve) at the valve on top of the cylinder. Do not disconnect any appliance unless the LPG cylinder is being relocated away from danger.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Stay informed - listen to emergency broadcasters (https://www.emv.vic.gov.au/responsibilities/victorias-warning-system/emergency-broadcasters/list) and monitor warnings.
Impacts in your area:
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • You may lose services including power, water, sewerage and telephone due to flooding.
  • Main roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding.
  • Relocate your stock, fodder and machinery to higher ground if you have not already done so.  
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 11:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

properties.webBody:
This Major Flood Warning is being issued for Avoca River downstream of Charlton. 

Avoca River downstream of Charlton Town: 
  • Major flooding may occur along the Avoca River downstream of Charlton Town.
  • The Avoca River at Quambatook is currently at 2.30 metres and rising slowly, with moderate flooding. The Avoca River at Quambatook may exceed the major flood level (2.40 m) Thursday evening. The river level may reach around 2.50 metres Friday morning.
Move to higher ground. Act now - immediately take actions to protect your life and property.

Maintain vigilance and pre-plan your action if conditions deteriorate. 
What you should do: 

  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater. 
  • Decide if you will evacuate if it becomes necessary. 
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
If you choose to leave: 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave. 
If you are travelling: 
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around and find a safe alternative route. 
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.   
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated. 
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow. 
Stay informed - listen to emergency broadcasters and monitor warnings.
Impacts in your area: 
  • There will be several low level farm crossings which intersect rivers that will be inundated. 
  • Main roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 09:30 am or as the situation changes.

Mosquito Alert: 
With the recent floods in many areas across Victoria, the risk of mosquito breeding is high. You can reduce your risk of being bitten and getting sick by: 
  • Cover up - wear long, loose-fitting clothing 
  • Use repellents that contain picaridin or DEET 
  • Use mosquito nets or insect screens. 
  • Limit activity outdoors and move indoors if possible. 
Learn more about how to protect yourself and your family at www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/campaigns/beat-the-bite

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Warning
properties.webBody:
This Warning is being issued for Bogong Village and Falls Creek
 and replaces the warning issued 3:37 PM pm on Monday 17/10/2022  for the same event.

There is still a risk in this area. Although the high risk has passed, there continues to be a risk of land slide as further rainfall is forecast later in the week

The road is open to Falls Creek residents and permitted drivers only. 

  • A landslide has occurred on the Bogong - High Plains Road at Bogong Village.
  • There is a slow moving active landslide on Bogong High Plains Road in the area near Spring Saddle Track above Bogong Village.
  • After recent heavy rainfall, cracking has been identified in the area around Spring Saddle Track and debris has been moving from below the track onto the Bogong - High Plains Road.
  • Regional Roads Victoria has undertaken Geo-technical investigations at the site and implemented traffic management measures limiting road usage - Only open to permitted drivers and  Falls Creek residents . 
  • When the road will fully re-open has not been determined and will depend on weather conditions and ongoing management of the landslide risk.
  • Regional Roads Victoria will continue to monitor the landslide risk and potential impact on Bogong - High Plains Road.
  • Geo-technical experts will complete assessments of the site and determine the best course of action to address the risk
Stay safe by avoiding fallen trees and powerlines, blocked or damaged roads and the area in general. Be aware of other hazards caused by the landslide.

The Bogong High - Plains Road at Bogong IS NOW CLOSED for general traffic from Mt Beauty.

Road users must have permission to enter or exit Falls Creek or the Bogong Village from either direction on the Bogong High - Plains Road. 

What you should do:
  • If you have chosen to remain, please monitor the road conditions. 
  • If another landslide occurs, act quickly.
  • If you are outside when a landslide occurs, move quickly and keep clear of embankments, trees, power lines and poles.
  • If you are inside, move to the part of building that is furthest away from the approaching landslide and take shelter under a table or bench.
  • Stay away from the impacted area to allow emergency services to help affected communities.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.

Driving:
  • Plan your trip in advance - travel may take longer due to closed roads and poor driving conditions.
Impacts in your area:
The landslide has resulted in:
  • Fallen trees and branches.
  • Dangerous road conditions.

  • There is now no public access to Falls Creek and Bogong Village as the Bogong - High Plains Road is closed. Access is only for those permitted and Falls Creek residents.

WARNING - LANDSLIDE
Incident Location: Bogong Village and Falls Creek
Issue Date: Wednesday 19 October 2022, 03:13 pm
Next Update: Friday 21 October 2022, 04:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/24092/moreinfo

This Warning is being issued for Bogong Village and Falls Creek
 and replaces the warning issued 3:37 PM pm on Monday 17/10/2022  for the same event.

There is still a risk in this area. Although the high risk has passed, there continues to be a risk of land slide as further rainfall is forecast later in the week

The road is open to Falls Creek residents and permitted drivers only. 

- A landslide has occurred on the Bogong - High Plains Road at Bogong Village.
-   There      is a slow moving active landslide on Bogong High Plains Road in the area      near Spring Saddle Track above Bogong Village.
-   After      recent heavy rainfall, cracking has been identified in the area around      Spring Saddle Track and debris has been moving from below the track onto      the Bogong - High Plains Road.  
-   Regional      Roads Victoria has undertaken Geo-technical investigations at the site and      implemented traffic management measures limiting road usage - Only open to permitted drivers and  Falls Creek residents . 
-   When the road will fully re-open has not been      determined and will depend on weather conditions and ongoing management of      the landslide risk.
- Regional Roads Victoria will continue to monitor the landslide risk and potential impact on Bogong - High Plains Road.
- Geo-technical experts will complete assessments of the site and determine the best course of action to address the risk


Stay safe by avoiding fallen trees and powerlines, blocked or damaged roads and the area in general. Be aware of other hazards caused by the landslide. 

The Bogong High - Plains Road at Bogong IS NOW CLOSED for general traffic from Mt Beauty.

Road users must have permission to enter or exit Falls Creek or the Bogong Village from either direction on the Bogong High - Plains Road.

properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Wharparilla. 

  • Flooding is expected to impact residents in the area of O'Dwyer Road, Wharparilla.
Act now - take actions immediately to protect your life and property, and move to higher ground.
What you should do:
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 
  • Decide if you will evacuate if it becomes necessary. 
If you choose to leave: 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace. 
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave. 
If you are travelling: 
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route. 
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater. 
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated. 
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow. 
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Impacts in your area:  
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 03:00 pm or as the situation changes.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.location: Loddon River Loddon Weir to Kerang
properties.webBody:
This Major Flood Warning is being issued for Loddon Weir to Kerang.

Loddon River Loddon Weir to Kerang: 
  • Major flooding is occurring along the Loddon River Loddon Weir to Kerang. The Loddon River at Downstream (D/S) Loddon Weir is currently at 5.31 metres and falling slowly with minor flooding. 
  • The Loddon River at Appin South is currently at 3.47 metres and rising slowly, with major flooding. The Loddon River at Appin South may peak near 3.50 metres Friday morning. 
  • The Loddon River at MV Hwy Bridge (Kerang) is currently at 77.56 m Australian Height Datum (AHD) and rising slowly, with moderate flooding (77.50 m AHD). The Loddon River at MV Hwy Bridge (Kerang) may reach the major flood level (77.80 m) Friday afternoon. The river level may reach around 78.00 metres overnight Friday into Saturday. Further rises are possible to around the January 2011 flood peak of 78.03 m AHD.
Flood water is anticipated to be similar to the January 2011 floods at Kerang and surrounds, but remain below the levee.

If you choose to stay you will need to be self sufficient for the period of isolation. 

Leaving now is the safest option, before conditions become too dangerous. Now is the time to consider making arrangements to stay with family and friends or alternative options outside of the forecast impacted area.
What you should do: 

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Decide if you will evacuate if it becomes necessary. 
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Farmers should move livestock and machinery to higher ground.
If you choose to leave: 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
If you are travelling: 
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around and find a safe alternative route. 
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated. 
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds. 
You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings. 

Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • Widespread flooding of the area. 
  • Homes and towns are likely to be isolated. 
  • Some areas will be likely to lose services including power, water, sewerage and telephone due to flooding.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 11:00 am or as the situation changes.

Mosquito Alert: 
With the recent floods in many areas across Victoria, the risk of mosquito breeding is high. You can reduce your risk of being bitten and getting sick by:
  • Cover up - wear long, loose-fitting clothing. 
  • Use repellents that contain picaridin or DEET. 
  • Use mosquito nets or insect screens.
  • Limit activity outdoors and move indoors if possible. 
Learn more about how to protect yourself and your family at www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/campaigns/beat-the-bite

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods) 
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.location: Goulburn River Lake Eildon to Seymour
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Goulburn River Lake Eildon to Seymour.

MAJOR FLOODING CONTINUING AT McCOYS BRIDGE
MODERATE FLOODING OCCURRING DOWNSTREAM OF LAKE EILDON, SEYMOUR AND SHEPPARTON AND MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT MURCHISON
Major flooding is continuing at McCoys Bridge during Thursday. The major flood peak along the Goulburn River is now downstream of McCoys Bridge and approaching the Murray River
Further rainfall is forecast from Thursday, which may lead to renewed river level rises. The situation is being closely monitored, and warnings will be updated as necessary.
Goulburn River Lake Eildon to Seymour:
Moderate flooding is occurring along the Goulburn River Lake Eildon to Seymour.
The Goulburn River downstream of Lake Eildon is currently at 4.25 metres, above the moderate flood level (4.00 m) and steady. The Goulburn River downstream of Lake Eildon is expected to remain above the moderate flood level (4.00 m) for the remainder of Thursday and during Friday.
The Goulburn River at Seymour is currently at 5.77 metres and steady, with moderate flooding. The Goulburn River at Seymour is expected to remain above the moderate flood level (5.20 m) for the remainder of Thursday into Friday.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater. 
What you should do:

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Be prepared to move household items to higher ground, on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds. 
  • Farmers should move livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • If you are using a generator, do not attempt to connect it to the wiring of your home. This is dangerous and illegal.   
  • A generator should only be used outside, with an extension cord to supply power direct to appliances such as the fridge or freezer. Using a generator indoors creates a number of safety risks including the potential for carbon monoxide poisoning or a fire.
If you choose to leave early for a safer place
  • Ensure all electrical and gas-powered heating and cooking appliances are turned off. 
  • Turn off all switches at the main electrical switchboard, including the Main Switch. 
  • Unplug all your appliances. 
  • You should turn off your gas supply by locating your gas metre and turning the gas supply service valve to the OFF position by rotating the handle to so that it is horizontal.
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave. 
  • Due to recent rainfalls roads have significantly deteriorated, drive with extreme caution.   
  • Animals are taking refuge on roadways, drive with caution and remain vigilant of wildlife. 
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Recovery:
Flood Recovery Hotline is a single state-wide number, 1800 560 760, that Victorians impacted by the October 2022 floods can call for help or assistance with: 
  • Register for clean-up on private property 
  • Navigating financial and other support 
  • Access to temporary accommodation Mental health and wellbeing support 
The recovery hotline is open from 7:30am-7:30pm everyday.   Call 1800 560 760 (press 9 to speak to an interpreter)
Impacts in your area:
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
When you have been advised it is safe to return
  • Only turn your power on at the main electrical switchboard if water has not entered the property. 
  • If water has entered your property, do not put the power back on until the property wiring has been tested by a licensed electrician. 
  • If any appliances have been inundated, do not plug them in or switch them on until they have been tested by a licensed electrician. 
  • For more information visit: https://esv.vic.gov.au/safety-education/emergencies/electrical-emergency/

Health Impacts
  • Avoid contact with floodwaters to prevent illness. Floodwaters may contain sewage and other contaminants.  
  • Stay out of the water - skin contact with floodwater or mud can cause illness and skin infections. Cover cuts and if you are injured during your clean up; clean the wound and contact your doctor immediately.   
  • Private water supplies may also be contaminated from floodwater, debris and chemicals. If your water supply tastes, looks or smells unusual, do not use it for drinking, preparing food, and do not give it to animals.
  • Medicines, stored at home and affected by flood water may now be unsafe and extreme caution should be taken in trying to salvage any medicines. 
  • Mosquitoes can also breed rapidly in stagnant waters. Drain any water from containers such as plant pots, tyres, buckets, and roof gutters to control mosquitos around your home.  
  • Flooding can also cause excessive mould growth which must be cleaned up before moving back to your home as it can make you sick. 
  • Flooding can cause sewage to overflow inside your home. Contact with sewage can make people sick, so contaminated areas must be cleaned and disinfected.
  • Any damaged gas or electricity supplies need to be declared safe by a qualified electrician or plumber. Do not use a portable generator indoors, they can produce carbon monoxide gas which could build up in a confined space and make you sick or be fatal. 
  • Food safety should also be considered and ALL food that has been flood damaged should be thrown away  including canned and packaged foods.   

This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 03:20 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • Flood Recovery Hotline is a single state-wide number, 1800 560 760,  that Victorians impacted by the October 2022 floods can call for help or assistance with: Navigating available supports mental health and wellbeing support The recovery hotline is open from 7:30am-7:30pm everyday. Call 1800 560 760 If your home is flooding and you need emergency assistance Call 000 If your home is about to flood Call VICSES on 132 500 
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
  • It is important to look after your mental health and that of friends, family and neighbours. If at any time you are worried about your mental health or the mental health of a loved one, call Lifeline 13 11 14 or the Suicide Call Back Service on 1300 659 467

Register.Find.Reunite
Red Cross has opened Register.Find.Reunite and is urging people affected by the Victorian Floods to get in touch with their families and friends. Register.Find.Reunite helps find and reunite family, friends and loved ones during a disaster. People can register on the Red Cross website at register.redcross.org.au, or by phone at 1800 727 077

properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for downstream of Barham to Wentworth.

As flood water moves downstream, river level rises and significant major flooding is expected at Torrumbarry and Barham. Forecasts for Swan Hill and downstream along the Murray River will be refined once there is more certainty in the expected peak at Echuca Wharf.

Murray River downstream of Barham to Wentworth:

  • Major flooding is possible at Swan Hill. Minor flooding is occurring along the Murray River at Wakool Junction and Boundary Bend, and possible at Mildura and Wentworth.
  • The Murray River at Swan Hill may exceed the minor flood level (4.50 metres) early next week. Depending on the observed peak level at Echuca, the river level may reach the major flood level (4.70 metres) around 28-30 October. This is similar to the October 1993 flood event.
  • The Murray River at Wakool Junction may reach the moderate flood level (10.50 metres) around the end of October.
  • The Murray River at Boundary Bend may reach around 8.30 metres early November, with minor flooding. Further rises are possible.
  • The Murray River at Mildura Weir may reach the minor flood level (36.00 metres AHD) mid November. Further rises are possible.The Murray River at Wentworth may reach the minor flood level (32.08 metres AHD) during Friday. The river level may reach around 32.30 metres AHD early November, with minor flooding. Further rises are possible.

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

Consequences of flooding along the Murray River will vary between NSW and Victoria. For more information relevant to your area please check: www.ses.nsw.gov.au in New South Wales and www.emergency.vic.gov.au in Victoria.
What you should do: 
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels online by visiting wwww.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings
  • Floodwater is dangerous - do not drive through floodwater. Do not overestimate the capability of your vehicle. It doesnt take much to make your car become unstable, lose traction or wash away.
Impacts in your area: 
  • High river levels may cause flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Some agricultural land may be vulnerable to flooding. Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Local roads may be closed.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 11:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

This Flood Watch is being issued for Warracknabeal and Yarriambiack Creek. 

Floodwater in the Yarriambiack Creek is travelling slowly downstream from the Wimmera River to Warracknabeal. The peak is likely to take days to reach Warracknabeal. 

Flooding may impact the Warracknabeal Fauna Park at Apex Park (Craig Ave) and Warracknabeal Caravan Park.  Several buildings south of Warracknabeal may be impacted by flooding along Dumbuoy Road (west of Cemetery Road). 

Floodwater may cut access to roads along Yarriambiack Creek in and surrounding Warracknabeal, these include: 
  • Jeparit-Warracknabeal Road
  • Cemetery Road 
  • Dumbuoy Road

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
