properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
MAJOR FLOODING CONTINUING AT McCOYS BRIDGE
MODERATE FLOODING OCCURRING DOWNSTREAM OF LAKE EILDON between SEYMOUR AND SHEPPARTON 
AND 
MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT MURCHISON

Major flooding is continuing at McCoys Bridge during Thursday. The Major flood peak along the Goulburn River is now downstream of McCoys Bridge and approaching the Murray River.

Further rainfall is forecast from Thursday, which may lead to renewed river level rises. The situation is being closely monitored, and warnings will be updated as necessary.

Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton:
Major flooding is occurring along the Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton.
The Goulburn River at McCoys Bridge is currently at 10.55 metres and steady, with Major flooding. 
The Goulburn River at McCoys Bridge is likely to remain above the Major flood level (10.20 m) for the remainder of Thursday into Friday.

Goulburn River Seymour to Shepparton:
Moderate flooding is easing along the Goulburn River Seymour to Shepparton.
The Goulburn River at Murchison is currently at 10.09 metres and falling, with minor flooding. 
The Goulburn River at Murchison is likely to remain above the minor flood level (9.00 m) for the remainder of Thursday and into Friday.
The Goulburn River at Shepparton fell below the major flood level (11.00 m) Thursday morning and is currently at 10.90 metres and steady, with moderate flooding. The Goulburn River at Shepparton is likely to remain above the moderate flood level (10.70 m) for the remainder of Thursday into Friday.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do:
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Be prepared to move household items to higher ground, or on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds. 
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground, if still safe to do.
Generators
  • If you are using a generator, Do not attempt to connect it to the wiring of your home. This is dangerous and illegal.   
  • A generator should only be used outside, with an extension cord to supply power direct to appliances such as the fridge or freezer. Using a generator indoors creates a number of safety risks including the potential for carbon monoxide poisoning or a fire.

If you choose to leave early for a safer place
  • Ensure all electrical and gas-powered heating and cooking appliances are turned off. 
  • Turn off all switches at the main electrical switchboard, including the Main Switch. 
  • Unplug all your appliances. 
  • You should turn off your gas supply by locating your gas metre and turning the gas supply service valve to the OFF position by rotating the handle to so that it is horizontal.
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.

If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.

If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
  • Stay informed - listen to emergency broadcasters (https://www.emv.vic.gov.au/responsibilities/victorias-warning-system/emergency-broadcasters/list) and monitor warnings.
Recovery:
  • Flood Recovery Hotline is a single state-wide number, 1800 560 760, that Victorians impacted by the October 2022 floods can call for help or assistance with: 
  • Register for clean-up on private property 
  • Navigating financial and other support 
  • Access to temporary accommodation Mental health and wellbeing support 
  • The recovery hotline is open from 7:30am-7:30pm everyday.   Call 1800 560 760 (press 9 to speak to an interpreter)

Impacts in your area:

  • High river levels and potential flooding may still affect areas close to rivers and streams. 
  • Flooding above floor level of some single-story home may still be occurring in some locations.    
  • Main roads and bridges may still be closed due to flooding, or low level flooding along residential streets.
  • For more information on road closures go to traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • Snakes, spiders and rats may try to find shelter in your home, even if raised. Protect yourself against mosquito bites.
When you have been advised it is safe to return:
  • Only turn your power on at the main electrical switchboard if water has not entered the property. 
  • If water has entered your property, do not put the power back on until the property wiring has been tested by a licensed electrician. 
  • If any appliances have been inundated, do not plug them in or switch them on until they have been tested by a licensed electrician. 
  • For more information visit: https://esv.vic.gov.au/safety-education/emergencies/electrical-emergency/
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 10:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • Flood Recovery Hotline is a single state-wide number, 1800 560 760, that Victorians impacted by the October 2022 floods can call for help or assistance with: Register for clean-up on private property;  Navigating financial and other support;  Access to temporary accommodation;  Mental health and wellbeing support.  The recovery hotline is open from 7:30am-7:30pm everyday.   Call 1800 560 760 (press 9 to speak to an interpreter).  If your home is flooding and you need emergency assistance Call 000.  If your home is about to flood Call VICSES on 132 500.
  •  If there is potential for flooding in your area, move your animals, fodder and machinery to higher ground early if it is safe to do so.   
  • Relocate and separate bulls and stallions from the mob in flood-prone areas when a flood alert is issued. They are not suitable for holding in confined spaces on a flood mound with other animals.  
  • Maintain several days of feed reserves above the flood level as wet conditions may make farm roads impassable.   
  •  Check animals that have been standing in mud or water for extended periods for health problems. 
  • For more information go to: https://agriculture.vic.gov.au/farm-management/emergency-management/floods/how-to-prepare-for-flood
Health impacts
  • Private water supplies may also be contaminated from floodwater, debris and chemicals. If your water supply tastes, looks or smells unusual, do not use it for drinking, preparing food, and do not give it to animals. 
  • Medicines, stored at home and affected by flood water may now be unsafe and extreme caution should be taken in trying to salvage any medicines. 
  • Mosquitoes can also breed rapidly in stagnant waters. Drain any water from containers such as plant pots, tyres, buckets, and roof gutters to control mosquitos around your home. 
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
Register.Find.Reunite
Red Cross has opened Register.Find.Reunite. and is urging people affected by the Victorian Floods to get in touch with their families and friends. Register.Find.Reunite. helps find and reunite family, friends and loved ones during a disaster. People can register on the Red Cross website at register.redcross.org.au, or by phone at 1800 727 077.

properties.webBody:
This Flood Watch is being issued for the Ovens and King River Catchment.

Renewed river level rises are expected and minor to moderate flooding may develop in the flood watch area from Saturday.

A low pressure system is forecast to bring rainfall and thunderstorms across Victoria from Friday, with the potential for isolated heavy falls. It will be followed by another rain-bearing system over the weekend for central and eastern parts of the state. Further widespread showers and rain are possible for early next week.

Catchments in the Flood Watch area are saturated, many of which are experiencing ongoing flooding due to recent rainfall.

Renewed river level rises are expected and minor to moderate flooding may develop in the watch area from Saturday. Catchments with existing warnings where river levels are elevated may see renewed flooding potentially to major flood levels from early next week at some locations. Renewed river rises are not expected to increase the currently forecast major flood peaks along the Murray River.

Minor flood warnings from previous rainfall are current for the Ovens River downstream of Rocky Point and the King River
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do:
  • Decide what you and your family will do if flooding impacts you. For information on how to prepare go to www.ses.vic.gov.au/get-ready/floodsafe.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Review your emergency plan and check your emergency kit is fully stocked, if you have one. Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.

Impacts in your area: 
  • High river levels and surrounding areas may be flooded.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 02:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Campaspe River Downstream of Rochester.

Campaspe River downstream of Rochester: 
  • Moderate flooding is occurring along the Campaspe River downstream of Rochester. The river level along the Campaspe River at Echuca at 4:00 pm Thursday was 94.49 m AHD and falling slowly, above the moderate flood level. 
  • The river is expected to continue falling slowly, but remain around the moderate flood level overnight Thursday and into Friday. 
  • Renewed rises are likely in coming days due to flood waters backing up from the Murray River.
Echuca has been impacted. If you are located in this area you are in danger - act now to protect yourself and move to higher ground. 

Leaving now is the safest option, before conditions become too dangerous. Follow this link for latest Evacuation Route.

A relief centre is open at Bendigo Showgrounds, Holmes Street, Bendigo.
What you should do: 

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
  • Decide if you will evacuate if needed.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
If you choose to leave: 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave. 
If you are travelling: 
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around and find a safe alternative route. 
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated. 
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds. 
You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings. 

Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in many locations.
  • Widespread flooding of the area.
  • Homes and towns are likely to be isolated.
  • Some areas will be likely to lose services including power, water, sewerage and telephone due to flooding.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Mosquito Alert:
With the recent floods in many areas across Victoria, the risk of mosquito breeding is high. You can reduce your risk of being bitten and getting sick by
  • Cover up - wear long, loose-fitting clothing 
  • Use repellents that contain picaridin or DEET 
  • Use mosquito nets or insect screens.
  • Limit activity outdoors and move indoors if possible. 
Learn more about how to protect yourself and your family at www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/campaigns/beat-the-bite

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods) 
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.text: EMERGENCY WARNING - RIVERINE FLOOD - Move to Higher Ground Incident Location: Campaspe River Downstream of Rochester Issue Date: Friday 21 October 2022, 12:38 am Next Update: Friday 21 October 2022, 12:00 pm More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/24287/moreinfo This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Campaspe River Downstream of Rochester. Campaspe River downstream of Rochester: - Moderate flooding is occurring along the Campaspe River downstream of Rochester. The river level along the Campaspe River at Echuca at 4:00 pm Thursday was 94.49 m AHD and falling slowly, above the moderate flood level. - The river is expected to continue falling slowly, but remain around the moderate flood level overnight Thursday and into Friday. - Renewed rises are likely in coming days due to flood waters backing up from the Murray River. Echuca has been impacted. If you are located in this area you are in danger - act now to protect yourself and move to higher ground. Leaving now is the safest option, before conditions become too dangerous. Follow this link for latest Evacuation Route. A relief centre is open at Bendigo Showgrounds, Holmes Street, Bendigo.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Murray River downstream of Tocumwal to Barham
properties.webBody:
This Major Flood Warning is being issued for Murray River downstream of Tocumwal to Barham. 

Murray River downstream of Tocumwal to Barham:

Major flooding is occurring at Echuca, Moama, Torrumbarry, Barham.

The Murray River at Echuca may reach around 94.80 metres during Sunday, with major flooding. This level is similar to the October 1993 flood event (94.77 m AHD). The river level may possibly reach around 95.00 metres during Tuesday.

The Murray River at Torrumbarry Weir may reach around 7.85 metres around 24-29 October, with major flooding. This is higher than the January 1974 flood.

The Murray River at Barham may reach 6.20 metres around 24-29 October, with major flooding. This is higher than the October 1993 and 2016 floods. Further rises are possible.

Move to higher ground. Act now - immediately take actions to protect your life and property.
What you should do: 
Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater. 
Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater. 
Decide if you will evacuate if it becomes necessary. 

If you choose to leave: 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave. 
If you are travelling: 
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around and find a safe alternative route. 
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.     
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated. 
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow. 
Stay informed - listen to emergency broadcasters and monitor warnings.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in many locations. 
  • Consequences of flooding along the Murray River will vary between NSW & Victoria. for more information relevant to your area, please check: www.ses.nsw.gov.au in NSW and  www.emergency.vic.gov.au in Victoria.
  • Main roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 11:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for the Murray River downstream of Hume Dam to Tocumwal.

This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch & Act issued on 20/10/22 at 1.07pm.

MAJOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT ECHUCA AND MOAMA, WITH FLOOD LEVELS SIMILAR TO THE 1993 FLOOD POSSIBLE FROM SUNDAY

Recent heavy rainfall has resulted in rapid river level rises and major flooding along the Goulburn and Campaspe Rivers. River levels along the Campaspe River at Rochester peaked on Friday last week and river levels along the Goulburn River at McCoys Bridge peaked Thursday morning.

These flood waters combined with flows down the Murray River have caused major flooding at Echuca and Moama. River levels at Echuca Wharf may reach levels similar to the 1993 flood (94.77 m AHD) from Sunday. Further rainfall is forecast during Thursday into early next week, which may cause renewed flooding along the Campaspe and Goulburn Rivers and may lead to further river rises at Echuca and Moama.

As this flood water moves downstream, river level rises and significant major flooding is expected at Torrumbarry and Barham. Forecasts for Swan Hill and downstream along the Murray River will be refined once there is more certainty in the expected peak at Echuca Wharf.

Murray River downstream of Hume Dam to Tocumwal

  • Minor flooding is occurring along the Murray River at Albury. Moderate flooding is occurring at Corowa and Tocumwal.
  • Subject to dam release and inflows from the Kiewa River, the Murray River at Albury may reach around 4.60 metres late Thursday, with minor flooding.
  • The Murray River at Corowa may reach around 6.20 metres during Saturday, with moderate flooding.
  • The Murray River at Yarrawonga Downstream fell below the minor flood level (6.40 metres) around 11:30 pm Wednesday.
  • The Murray River at Tocumwal peaked near 6.90 metres around 10:00 pm Tuesday and is currently at 6.73 metres and falling, with moderate flooding.
Flood operations are being conducted by the Murray-Darling Basin Authority (MDBA) at Hume Dam to manage inflows from the upper Murray, Mitta Mitta River and other tributaries.

MDBA are working closely with the Bureau and WaterNSW to plan release strategies.


Consequences of flooding along the Murray River will vary between NSW and Victoria. For more information relevant to your area, please check: www.ses.nsw.gov.au in NSW and www.emergency.vic.gov.au in Victoria.

Much of the flooding impacts is occurring on the NSW side of the Murray River

Murray River - Emergency Area - Leave and Do Not Enter  Authorised by : Paul Lyddiard, Incident Controller, Southern Zone 

As a result of the dangerously high level of the Murray River and flood warnings remaining for the many tributaries that drain into the Murray River, the NSW State Emergency Service advises that the following areas of the Murray River are an emergency area under the State Emergency Services Act 1989 (NSW) (SES Act): 
  • downstream of Tocumwal Road Bridge to Barham Bridge. 

Under section 22 of the SES Act people are directed as follows: 
  • Leave the emergency area 
  • Do not enter the emergency area. This applies to all commercial and recreational users of the rivers.  No boats can enter the emergency area and people cannot enter the area for any recreational purpose such as fishing or swimming.  
  • Emergency Services, Roads and Maritime Services and council personnel are permitted to access the emergency area for emergency operations and enforcement.   

This takes immediate effect, and remains in place until the area is no longer deemed to be an emergency area. 

For further information contact: NSW State Emergency Service on 132500.

Prepare for flooding now. Take actions to protect your life and property against potential hazards caused by flooding.

Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater. 
What you should do:
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Decide if you will evacuate if it becomes necessary. 
  • If you are camping close to a creek or river, you may be at risk of flooding and need to move immediately to higher ground, away from waterways.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off all switches at the main electrical switchboard, including the Main Switch. 
  • Unplug all your appliances and if you can, lift them up so they will remain clear of any floodwater that may inundate your property.
  • Turn your solar system off at the inverter and then turn off at the switchboard (all switches on the switchboard should be in the OFF position). The solar system will have information on shut down procedures. 
  • Turn solar batteries off. Follow the shutdown procedure which will be close to battery system. Do not attempt to disassemble the battery or open any of the panels. 
  • You should turn off your gas supply by locating your gas meter and turning the gas supply service valve to the OFF position by rotating the handle to so that it is horizontal. 
  • Before leaving, make sure all LPG cylinders are closed (clockwise to close the cylinder valve) at the valve on top of the cylinder. Do not disconnect any appliance unless the LPG cylinder is being relocated away from danger.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.

Stay informed - listen to emergency broadcasters (https://www.emv.vic.gov.au/responsibilities/victorias-warning-system/emergency-broadcasters/list) and monitor warnings.
Impacts in your area:
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Main roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding.
  • Parks, tracks and campgrounds maybe closed due to flooding
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
  • Local roads may be closed due to impact of flood waters. 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 01:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
For health information and support contact the below organisations: Lifeline on www.lifeline.org.au or phone 13 11 14. 
Beyond Blue on www.beyondblue.org.au or phone 1300 224 636. 
Kids Helpine on www.kidshelp.com.au or phone 1800 551 800. 
SANE Australia on www.sane.org or phone 1800 187 263.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
Register Find Unite - Red Cross  
Red Cross has opened Register.Find.Reunite. and is urging people affected by the Victorian Floods to get in touch with their families and friends. Register.Find.Reunite. helps find and reunite family, friends and loved ones during a disaster. People can register on the Red Cross website at register.redcross.org.au, or by phone at 1800 727 077.

properties.webBody:
This Flood Watch is being issued for Loddon River downstream of Kerang and Bendigo & Bullock Creeks.

Bendigo and Bullock Creeks:
  • River levels are elevated along the Bendigo and Bullock Creeks.
Loddon River downstream of Kerang:
  • River levels are elevated along the Loddon River downstream of Kerang.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Avoid contact with any floodwaters to prevent illness. Floodwaters may contain sewage and other contaminants
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes. 
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings. 
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground. 
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are informed and OK.
Impacts in your area
  • Areas around rivers and streams may be flooded.
  • Local roads may be impacted by floodwater.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service 

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 09:30 am or as the situation changes.

Mosquito Alert:
With the recent floods in many areas across Victoria, the risk of mosquito breeding is high. You can reduce your risk of being bitten and getting sick by:
  • Cover up - wear long, loose-fitting clothing 
  • Use repellents that contain picaridin or DEET Use mosquito nets or insect screens.
  • Limit activity outdoors and move indoors if possible. 
  • Learn more about how to protect yourself and your family at http://www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/campaigns/beat-the-bite

properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is for Barmah and Lower Moira. 

  • An Evacuation Warning remains current, but as of 6.00pm tonight (now) it is now too late to leave. 
  • The flood is expected to continue impacting the Barmah and Lower Moira area which means there is no longer enough time to safely leave your property.
  • This Emergency Warning replaces the Evacuate Immediately - Emergency Warning issued at 2.36pm 20/10/2022.
It is now too late to leave for people in Barmah and Lower Moira community. If you have not evacuated, you should shelter in the highest location possible.
What you should do: 

If you have not already evacuated: 
  • Stay where you are and shelter in the highest location possible. 
  • Be aware that you may be isolated by floodwater for a significant amount of time. 
  • Access roads out of the area are likely to be closed due to flooding.
  • Check you have enough food, drinking water and medications - if you do not, phone Triple Zero (000) for assistance. 

If you have already evacuated: 
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued. 
  • Register at a relief centre so that your friends, family and authorities can be informed that you are safe. 
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings. 
  • An Emergency Relief Centre has been established at the Nathalia Community Sports Centre, 42 Robertson Street, Nathalia.

Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 

This evacuation warning is likely to remain in place until 21/10/2022 10.00am .
Impacts in your area: 
  • Flood levels may continue to rise and spread in this area.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

The next update is expected by 21/10/2022 10:00 am or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au

  • Major flooding is easing along the Goulburn River Seymour to Shepparton.
  • The Goulburn River at Murchison peaked at 12.05 metres around midnight Saturday into Sunday and is currently at 10.22 metres, above the moderate flood level (10.20 m) and falling slowly. The Goulburn River at Murchison is likely to fall below the moderate flood level (10.20 m) Wednesday night. The river level is likely to remain above the minor flood level (9.00 m) during Thursday.
  • The Goulburn River at Shepparton peaked at 12.06 metres around 09:08 pm Sunday 16 October and is currently at 11.15 metres, above the major flood level (11.00 m) and falling slowly. The Goulburn River at Shepparton is likely to fall below the major flood level (11.00 m) Thursday morning.
    • Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
